awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Electrochemically driven Mechanical Energy Harvesting
awd_abstract_narration:
Energy harvesting, which is any technology that converts otherwise wasted energy of various forms into electricity, represents a key component in energy sustainability for modern society. In mechanical energy harvesting alone, several types of electric power generators have been demonstrated, including piezoelectric, electrokinetic and triboelectric generators. These devices have enabled a wide range of applications, from small self-powered devices to auxiliary power units for wearable electronics. However, due to the short-lived electric current, these power generators are most efficient for vibrational energy harvesting at a relatively high frequency and inherently limited in the low frequency regime where every-day human activities such as walking take place. This research project aims to develop a unique type of mechanical energy harvester that exploits the typical configuration of the electrochemical cells in batteries and specifically targets harvesting low frequency motions. Such energy harvesters may work as auxiliary generators, powering ubiquitous computing, communications and wearable electronics. The project will also offer interdisciplinary research experience in experimental design, computational materials science and mechanics to both undergraduates and graduates at MIT and Penn State, as well as enhance minority involvement and participation in science and engineering, and stimulate the interests of students in the research field of innovative energy-storage materials and energy harvesting.

The objective of this project is to uncover the underlying mechanisms of electrochemically driven mechanical energy harvesting so as to control and optimize power and energy generation at targeted low frequency through an integrated experimental-modeling approach. To fulfill this goal, the team will adopt a multiscale method to model the stress-voltage coupling and to predict current and power output of mechanical energy harvesters. Guided by the modeling results, mechanical energy harvester prototypes will be fabricated, tested and diagnosed. The integrated experimental-modeling approach enables a fundamental understanding of the key design parameters that govern the performance of mechanical energy harvesters in particular, and helps foster transformative progress for understanding a broad range of stress-mediated electrochemical processes in general.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview. Conversion from mechanical energy to electricity represents an important route to scavenge energy from living environment, such as human activities, to power mobile consumer electronics and micro/nanosystems. The majority of existing harvesters including piezoelectric, triboelectric, electromagnetic energy generators, are efficient in collecting high-frequency (>10 Hz) mechanical energies, but show considerably low output when operating at low frequencies (< 1 Hz), a dominant frequency range of ambient environmental energy resources. Inherent to the time scale of ion diffusion across liquid electrolytes, an electrochemical cell converts chemical energy to electricity and vice versa at relatively low frequencies. Unequal mechanical work imparted into the electrodes can drive ion diffusion across electrolytes, thereby converting mechanical to chemical energies. Such an electrochemical platform embryonates a new class of mechanical energy harvesters at low frequencies, complementary to the classical high-frequency energy generators.

This project aims to develop a fundamental understanding of the electrochemomechanical mechanisms that control power generation and cyclability in electrochemically driven energy harvesting at targeted frequency, thereby providing rational guidance for the design and optimization of large-area mechanical energy harvesters, sensors and actuators. The team has developed a thermodynamic theory and revealed that there exist two distinct regimes for electrochemically driven mechanical energy harvesting, enabled by pressure or molar-volume asymmetries of the electrodes, respectively. The pressure-asymmetry based energy harvester has been previously realized by the team. The team then prototyped a new energy harvester based on the molar-volume difference in an intercalation-conversion electrode couple. The molar-volume asymmetry enabled energy harvesters possess several advantages over the pressure asymmetry-based harvesters in terms of its efficiency, scalability, durability, and safety. In parallel, the team has developed a chemomechanical model to simulate the device performance, coupling mechanics with electrochemical kinetics. The integrated theory-experimental-modeling approach is enabling a fundamental understanding of the electrochemomechanical processes, which facilitates further optimization of the current and energy output and cyclability of the mechanical energy harvester.

Intellectual Merit: Exploiting mechanical-electrochemical coupling in electrode materials to realize mechanical energy harvesters is innovative and exciting. The thermodynamic theory and the multiphysics model developed within this project lays down the framework for the coupling between mechanical stress and Li transport kinetics, which enables rational design of materials and microstructures in electrochemical energy harvesters, offering significant advantages over phenomenological approaches in conventional device development. The experimental design of the intercalation-conversion electrode couple maximizes the energy input for the energy harvester. Taken together, the integrated theory-experimental-modeling approach and the interdisciplinary nature of the conducted research will be helping foster transformative progress for the development of high-performance mechanical energy harvesters in particular and for understanding a broad range of electrochemomechanical processes in general.

Broader Impact: In addition to laying down the thermodynamic foundation for a new class of mechanical energy harvesters, our work sheds significant light on the practical design strategies for efficient mechanical harvesters at the low-frequency regime. The energy harvester may work as auxiliary generators, providing electrical energies to power ubiquitous computing and communications. The energy generator can be incorporated into and power a diverse set of wearable electronics. The PIs are converting the research findings into classroom teaching materials for both undergraduate and graduate students in MIT and PSU. The project is also offer interdisciplinary research experiences in experimental manipulation and computational materials science and mechanics to both undergraduates and graduates in the two collaborative institutions, enhancing minority involvement and participation in science and engineering, and stimulating the interests of students in the research field of innovative energy-storage and conversion materials and devices.


Last Modified: 07/29/2019
Modified by: Sulin Zhang

    Li/Zhang groups

    Working principle of the ICEC device for harvesting mechanical energy
  • a) The open circuit voltage can be ratchetted up to ~195 mV by repeated compression-decompression cycles. (b) After ratchetting, the ICEC device can output a high current of ~736.4 ?A cm-2. (c) Chemomechanical simulation of the stress evolution of the conversion electrode during the cycle.
    Li/Zhang groups
    Copyrighted
    Sulin Zhang
    Blasting power output induced by ratchetting
  • (a, b) The measured short-circuit current; c) The measured short-circuit current by stacking multilayers of electrodes with different S8 loadings; (d) Electricity generated during long-term repeated compressing-decompressing cycles, indicating excellent durability of the ICEC device.
    Li/Zhang groups
